Test driving IBM watsonx.ai, the role 
of AI in sustainability initiatives,

and the AI Bundle for IBM Z and LinuxONE—all 
on this episode of IBM Tech Now.

What's up y'all, my name is 
Ian, and I am back to bring

you the latest and greatest news and 
announcements about IBM technology.

To get the ball rolling today, IBM is excited 
to offer a 30-day demo, where you can chat

with a solo model to experience working with 
generative AI in the IBM watsonx.ai studio.

This means you can access some of our most popular 
AI models, ask them questions, and see how they

respond. It really gives you a taste of some 
of the capabilities of large language models.

In this first release of the watsonx.ai 
demo, you can access five model types.

During the AI solution development lifecycle, 
it’s important to be able to quickly test multiple

models, interact with them, collect feedback, and 
share them with peers. With this new demo tool,

we aim to pave the way for a future of accelerated 
time to value for popular common patterns.

To learn more about this 30-day demo 
or start a complete watsonx.ai trial,

check out the link in the 
description of this video.

Next up, the world recently celebrated 
Earth Day. With 2024 on track to be

the hottest year on record, it’s 
crucial to examine how data and AI

can be applied to many areas to help 
supercharge sustainability efforts.

When looking at how to use data and technology 
to advance sustainability initiatives across

the globe, we believe there are three core 
areas that every organization should focus on.

The first is sustainability strategy, 
data, and reporting. Essentially,

we should be using data and AI to drive 
a sustainability strategy while meeting

reporting requirements. AI can turn 
intel into insights faster, enabling

businesses to drive toward sustainability 
goals and financial targets more quickly.

The second is energy transition and 
climate resilience. We need to apply

AI and the Internet of Things to accelerate 
the transition to sustainable energy sources.

The third is intelligent asset, facility, and 
infrastructure management. This means leveraging

AI to build efficient physical operations, manage 
costs, and reduce the environmental footprint.

To learn more about the future of AI 
and sustainability, hit the link below.

To wrap things up today, the explosion 
in interest and adoption of AI is forcing

IT leaders to revisit their capacity 
plans and increase compute resources.

Many enterprises are realizing that to maximize 
the value of their AI investments, infrastructure

needs to scale rapidly and efficiently to deliver 
AI insights where and when they need them.

In 2022, IBM introduced 
the groundbreaking IBM z16,

featuring an on-chip AI inference accelerator 
focused on accelerating AI model execution.

Today, we are announcing the AI 
Bundle for IBM Z and LinuxONE.

This builds on the success of the 
IBM z16 or LinuxONE 4 by providing

new dedicated capacity for AI workloads 
with a highly optimized software stack.

With a curated suite of AI software, you 
can manage AI model lifecycles in one place,

allowing for the quick deployment 
of a wide range of use cases.

Additionally, by leveraging the IBM Telum 
processor with the Integrated Accelerator

for AI, you can run inferencing 
for high-volume workloads at scale.

To learn more about the AI Bundle for 
IBM Z and LinuxONE, hit the link below.

Thanks so much for joining me today 
for this episode of IBM Tech Now.

If you're interested in learning 
more about the topics I've covered,

make sure you explore the links 
in the description of this video.

And, again, please don't forget 
to subscribe to our channel to
stay up-to-date on what's going on in tech, now.
